title: 111_hr1341
content: The Act may be cited as the "Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program Act of 2009" and includes audit and investigation authorities. Section 121 of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to grant the Special Inspector General additional authority to conduct audits and investigations related to actions taken under the Act, with some exceptions. The Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program is granted additional authority to conduct audits and investigations under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. SEC. 3. PERSONNEL AUTHORITIES. Section 121(e) of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to grant the Special Inspector General certain employment authorities under title 5, United States Code. The Special Inspector General is restricted from making appointments six months after the enactment of the Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program Act of 2009. The Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program is granted employment authorities under title 5, United States Code. Appointments are restricted after six months of the enactment of the Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program Act of 2009. An annuitant receiving an annuity can continue to receive it if employed within the Office of the Special Inspector General, with a limit of 25 employees designated by the Special Inspector General. The Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program is granted employment authorities under title 5, United States Code. Appointments are restricted after six months of the enactment of the Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program Act of 2009. An annuitant receiving an annuity can continue to receive it if employed within the Office of the Special Inspector General, with a limit of 25 employees designated by the Special Inspector General. Pay periods begin after the date of enactment of the Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program Act of 2009. SEC. 4. RESPONSE TO AUDITS AND COOPERATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER ENTITIES. Section 121 of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to include corrective responses to audit problems and cooperation with other entities to avoid duplication of effort. The text discusses the establishment of a Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency to oversee the Troubled Asset Relief Program. Inspectors General from various entities are listed as members of the council to ensure effective cooperation and coordination. The establishment of a Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency to oversee the Troubled Asset Relief Program includes members from various entities to ensure cooperation and coordination. The Office of the Special Inspector General for the Troubled Asset Relief Program will continue until termination. SEC. 5. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to require the Special Inspector General to submit quarterly reports to Congress summarizing their activities. Additionally, a report assessing fund usage must be submitted by September 1, 2009. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 requires the Special Inspector General to submit quarterly reports to Congress summarizing their activities. A report assessing fund usage by financial institutions under TARP must be made public within 24 hours of submission. All reports submitted under this subsection will be available to the public. SEC. 6 amends the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 regarding funding for the Special Inspector General. SEC. 7 states that the Special Inspectors General for Iraq and Afghanistan Reconstruction will be members of the Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency until their respective offices are terminated.
